title: Fish-On NOW !
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: A fish alerting device for Ice Fishing with Tip Ups and automatic hook set systems. Ideal for bite notification when fishing during the day (loud buzzer) and at night (high brightness LED). You know the feeling, you're in the ice hut but you can't see your tip-up outside, or you are monitoring a few tip-ups and go to set a line and don't notice a tip-up has flagged. This device solves these issues and also enables you to fish at night. It will work with most tip-ups that have a spring loaded rod with a flag. It's simple, consisting of a mercury level switch, buzzer, led, switch, resistor and battery and costs just under $9 to make. To use, point "Fish-On Now!" down and push the switch forward to switch on. Then when it moves above level, it will buzz and light the LED. Flick the switch off to shut it up whilst setting your tip-ups. Consult your own regulations for permitted use (I don't know of any that don't allow it). Note: The automatic hook setter shown also in this picture is available in a newer version at: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:77050

• Use Customizer to choose your rod or tip-up diameter.

  • Print at 50% fill and 2 shells

  • Solder components together to fit in shell as per schematic

  • Use copious amounts of hot glue to put components in place on
    one side of the shell, making sure you can remove the battery and you haven't
    put glue on the mating surface.

  • Put the other half of the shell on, the rod holder and use the 2 clips (rectangles)
    over either end to hold it all together.

  • Wrap a small piece of duct tape around the mounting position on your tip-up
    (this stops it rotating)

  • Use 2 cable ties to attach "Fish-On Now!" to your tip-up.

  • If you're the kind of person that loses equipment in the water, then substitute for a non mercury switch
  • If you lose the battery in the water, that would be more of a risk as the decompose.
    :-)

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:536486 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=536486

Using the following options: second_letter = B
first_letter = C
Iphone 5 case

You know when you want to work on one of your many crochet projects but the hook you need has disappeared down the back of the sofa, or possibly rolled under the bookshelf, or by some other means gone to join the secret underground society of its fellows that all your craft supplies eventually escape to join? And you know how that always happens when the shops are shut and you can't buy a new one? Well fear not! This model allows you to print out a crochet hook of whatever dimension you want! Assuming that your 3D printer hasn't similarly got lost under a sofa cushion, of course. The SCAD code for this Thing is on GitHub at https://github.com/pozorvlak/crochet-hook.

• If you want a 10mm, 8mm or 6mm hook (US sizes P, -, J; UK sizes 000, 0, 4) that's 15cm (6in) long, then just download the relevant STL file and go to step 3.
  • If not, customize the length, diameter, grip thickness and so on to whatever your heart desires (your heart may find the chart of hook sizes at http://www.karpstyles.com/crochet/hook-chart.html useful in calibrating its desires), either by clicking the "Open in Customizer" button above or by downloading the SCAD file and editing it with OpenSCAD. All measurements are in millimetres.
  • Print the STL file: I've been using 20% infill. You probably want a raft to prevent curling. This stage will take a few minutes; you may find that crocheting helps you to pass the ti... oh.
  • File or sand off any rough edges; in particular you'll probably want to file down the steps on the throat.
  • Try to find your now long-forgotten crochet project.

title: Anti vibration mount for the Mobius camera for multirotors and FPV

description.text:
Version 2 is out! I suggest you print the new version instead of this one. Find it here: --> http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:546375 <-- A simple anti-vibration mount for the Mobius camera. The plates have 4 holes that will allow attachment to a DJI F450 with M3 screws. On the upper plate, the same holes can be used to run zip ties to lock the cam. Lateral grooves can be used both to attach the mount to the vehicle or the camera to the plate.
4 or 6 vibration dampeners can be used.
If you print it, thanks for sharing a photo! If have suggestions for a different version, contact me.
For the printing of the plates shown the photos I made the mistake of including a base in the printer option. Next time, I would print without a base. You want one but don't have a 3D printer? No problem! Ask me to print one for you through 3DHubs: https://www.3dhubs.com/rome/hubs/my3d

author: PersonalDrones

description.text:
Fan for cooling your prints on Makerfarm Prusa i3v printers. I haven't installed mine yet but I will update once I do. I will likely add an extra optional piece to direct the airflow better, but I will see how this does first. This one does require some hardware, please check the Instructions for a full list. --Update--
06/01/15 - Added an option for an M5x30 Bolt
14/02/15 - Added a shroud to amplify airflow near the print

Printed in ABS on a Makerfarm 8" Prusa i3v at 0.2mm layer height.
BOM:
1 x Cooling Fan Base
1 x Cooling Fan Flange
1 x 40mm Fan (Makerfarm kit comes with an extra)
4 x M3x16 Bolts (Makerfarm kit comes with some extras)
4 x M3 Nylon Lock Nuts (Makerfarm kit comes with some extras)
1 x M5 Nut
1 x M5x40 OR M5x30 Bolt I used the M5x40 bolt to attach the two pieces because it is what I had on hand. If you can't get one for some reason, let me know what you have access to and I can update the model. The holes on the Flange should be small enough to thread without the lock nuts, but I had some extra with the kit so I threw them on. There is also some extra room for a shroud to be added in the future to concentrate the airflow a bit.

title: Adjustable Spool Coaster Rail System and Things

description.text:
The concept is really simple - you print 2 (or more) rails and 4 (or more) coasters. Attach the rails parallel to each other next to your printer (with double sided tape or with screws), assemble the coasters (keep in mind the 'jaws' of the coasters are not identical to give you better control on the position - rotate them 180 degrees to move them by half a tooth, also 608 bearings are required) then position the coasters on the rails accordingly to your spool dimensions and that's pretty much it.
It was designed for PLA, I have no idea it it will work with other materials.

author: DougLR

description.text:
A Gaiwan Tea Set that is fully functional (when printed in food safe material).  These are lidded tea cups that have all necessary components to brew a cup of tea in your hand.  
Each piece was designed by tracing the surface in Inkscape and producing .dxf files.  The .dxf files were used with openscadÂ´s rotate_extrude with $fn=100 to have a nice smooth surface.   The stl files were scaled 15 fold in replicatorg, and some were flipped to make printing more successful.  I also used cloud.netfabb.com to polish some of the STL files for better slicing.

Print these parts in PLA (food safe) or other safe polymers.  It is actually quite useable at the temperatures used for preparation of green tea without melting the PLA.  I printed these on a home built Rostock (the original design of Johann Rocholl) using white PLA with 0.2mm layer heights, 180C temp with a CPU fan aimed at the hotend, and 80C heated build platform.  Cup and base had 0.05 infill, and lid had 0.5 infill.  I had the most trouble with printing a nice looking lid.  Slic3r was used for generating gcode and for the base and lid I used a 10mm brim to anchor the pieces to my heated build platform.

title: Airtripper geared bowden for mk7/8 drivergears

description.text:
I mixed the latest (V3) version of Airtripper bowden extruder (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:35404) with Terenceangs geared airtripper extruder (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:456095).
The latter was an old version of the extruder body but I used the gears from it. I removed the parts that weren't necessary for the new motor position and added a M10 nut for the bowden couplers (the ones that e.g. E3D ships).
The main axle is a M5 screw for the MK7/8 driver gears. The whole for the bearings are 10mm. I found these smaller ones in my local hobby shop.

Use the instructions from the Airtripper.  
I use 3 m5 spacers between the big cogwheel and the case, to keep the angle straight

title: FSR Holder for triangular Build Plate

description.text:
This thing holds a triangular Build plate (mine is cut from a regular mirror) and has room for 3 FSRs with 1/2" (12.7mm) diameter each.  
It is adjustable to fit not perfectly cut glass.

comments.text: hello. wonderful design! what do you do with the FSRs? is it possible to use their data outputs for bed leveling somehow?
comments.author: dmon88

comments.text:
Exactly. It is used as a replacement for the mechanical bed probe. Instead, the hotend pushes down directly on the printbed when probing. This pressure is detected by the FSRs. An attiny converts this analog signal into a simple on/off signal which is read in as a normal endstop.
If you search around a bit you will find the schematics and everything you need.

description.text:
With this rack you can utilize the space below a shelf for small round containers with herbs and spices (or anything else).
No drilling or glueing needed!
All that's needed is a removable board in the shelf.
The default settings will be suitable for a sixpack of the "Ostmann" spice jars which are probably quite common here in Germany.
Otherwise you can simply change the diameter and height of a jar, as well as the number of rows and columns and the thickness of the board under which you want to place it.

title: K8200/3DRAG dual motor Z axis with M8 rods

description.text:
Yet another modification of the K8200 Z-axis to prevent wobble, this time with standard M8 stainless steel rods and anti-backlash system using standard M8 hex nuts for the people who have another stepper motor and flex shaft coupler lying around and want to make as few changes as possible. You don't have to adjust the steps/mm value and all in all I think even though this modification doesn't improve the print quality al that much, it at least prevents the M8 threads from wearing by distributing the weight of the extruder arm (on the original design all its weight is only held by one(!) M8 hex nut, which is not even well-suited for building linear motion systems).
Like the design by floyd871, mine uses the following parts:
Motor-holder:http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:167650
Upper Z-Carriage Holder http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:175137 A documentation of all mods that I've made on my K8200 see
http://www.thinkering.de/cms/?p=469 and
http://www.thinkering.de/cms/?p=534

Besides the printed parts you will need:
-another M8 stainless steel rod. Its material is harder than that of the steel nut and will cut its way through irregularities.
-am M4 threaded rod for cutting into pieces and mounting the anti-backlash nut box to the arm extension
-8 M4 nuts and washers
-an M5 threaded rod for cutting into pieces for mounting the arm. Then you will also need 8 M5 washers and hex nuts. Alternatively 6 20mm M5 bolts should do as well
-an "M8 spring" you can get in hardware stores. Look at the photo above to see which one I got. Cut a piece of about 3cm and bend the cut end away from the center so that it doesn't get between nut and theraded rod while spinning.
-5 M8 hex nuts (2 to be mounted inside the box, to for fixing the axis on the top printed mount [use washers as well] and 1 optional one for counter tension on the flex shaft coupler.
-4 short countersunk M3 bolts with washers and nuts to assemble the printed motor mount.
-4 short (10mm max.) M3 bolts to mount the motor to the mount
-4 10mm M5 bolts to mount the motor mount to the frame. 2 can be scavenged from the original Lm8UU linear bearing holder at the end of the Z-axis arm.
-a total of 11 square M5 nuts for the extruded profiles (6 for the arm extension, on for the top bearing holder and 4 for the motor
mount.
-well, a NEMA 17 motor
-a 5->8mm flex shaft coupler
-a 608z ball bearing for the rod
-lubricant for the rod
Some assembly advice:
Don't make the anti-backlash assembly too tight and make sure it travels smoothely along the entire way before mounting.
Increase the motor current a little. I set the motor voltage to 670mV, that worked well.
Connect the second motor in parallel to the first one. For the motor I had lying around, the following modification worked to have it spin in the right direction:
Flat cable->Motor wires:
Blue -> green
Green->black
Yellow->red
Orange->blue Once everything is assembled you can print and attach the M5 and M4 caps to the naked threaded rod endings.

description.text: This is a simple lever and fulcrum that, combined with LEGO minifigures and children, turns into a catapult. Inspired by the "Made by Joel" website. http://madebyjoel.com/2012/05/small-catapult-toy.html Also, an opportunity to experiment with laser-cut parts in OpenSCAD, and to test laser-cutter offsets for press-fit peg-joints.

First laser-cut wasn't a success. Perfect tolerance in OpenSCAD creates a too-loose fit with the laser-cutter. Needed to add some xy-plane thickness to the pegs to account for material removed by the laser. Used minkowski() on the pegs to make them thicker:
-- 0.125mm recommended offset was too loose, needed glue.
-- 0.375mm appears to be a perfect press-fit offset (no hammering, no glue)
-- 0.5mm too-tight press-fit offset (had to hammer together, stripping a layer of laminate) Idea and initial offset dimensions from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:27736 Research suggests the laser cuts a v-shaped notch, widest closest to the cutting surface. Width and depth of the notch are presumably functions of the power and speed settings.
A 0.375mm offset worked best with 4.75mm (3/16") baltic birch plywood. Epilog 36-EXT, laser setting was SPEED=08, POWER=85 and FREQ=450. OpenSCAD code has lots of comments and test-modules.

During one of my camping trips this summer the knob on my 5 gal Coleman water jug snapped off right in my hand. While looking for a replacement I realized I could just draw and print one. I hope this is useful to others also.
.

I printed the handle in ABS and scaled it up by 0.5% in the XY direction.  It is a perfect fit. I'm sure it won't leak a drop.   I printed a short section of the nozzle in three different scalings before I settled on the size.  I used 2 perimeters and 30% infill.  I'm not worried about this one breaking!

title: A Minimalistic DVD Rack for Games and Movies
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This rack holds Blu-rays, DVDs, Xbox 360, Wii, and PlayStation 3 games very well. I designed it to be "modular" so that when my game collection gets bigger I can just print another tray and link the two together creating a tray "train". I am still working on the linking bits but so far it has been working really well. I considered cases placed in portrait or landscape orientation so that either work and are stable. My home entertainment center has short shelves so landscape works great for me. I did notice that when cases are inserted with a portrait orientation some cases with lose plastic covers will snag because my tolerances are probably .2-.4 mm on the tight side. Your mileage may vary.
Holds 8 DVDs
Rounded slats to make inserting DVDs easier
Print Time on Da Vinci at "normal" speeds = 1 hour 50 min
Raft = No
Supports = No
ABS Consumed = 10m
Project Size = 150 mm X 80 mm 25 mm
Maximum Capacity for 1 tray is 8 DVDs
Maximum Capacity for N number of trays Not linked = 8N
Maximum Capacity for N number of trays with dvd-link is (8N+(N-1))
1 Tray not linked = 8 DVDs
2 Trays linked = 17 DVDs
2 Trays not linked = 16 DVDs
3 Trays linked = 26 DVDs
3 Trays not linked = 24 DVDs
liking trays not only keeps the trays together and organized, but it also increases the maximum capacity of the entire collection.

I used FreeCAD, set of digital calipers and my imagination to get this idea off the ground. My Da Vinci 1.0 3D printer turned my STL into a reality.
Print DVD Rack file to create a single 8 DVD tray.
If you want to print multiple trays and link them together, print out the dvd joiner file and link multiple trays together. The joiner adds the space for an extra DVD between the 2 trays.
Maximum Capacity for 1 tray is 8 DVDs
Maximum Capacity for N number of trays Not linked = 8N
Maximum Capacity for N number of trays with dvd-link is (8N+(N-1))
1 Tray not linked = 8 DVDs
2 Trays linked = 17 DVDs
2 Trays not linked = 16 DVDs
3 Trays linked = 26 DVDs
3 Trays not linked = 24 DVDs
liking trays not only keeps the trays together and organized, but it also increases the maximum capacity of the entire collection.

title: Controller platform for Diatone FPV250 style quadcopter frames

description.text:
Everyone loves these inexpensive little quadcopter frames. I have the basic frame without the fpv cage arrangement on it. I wanted to strap the battery to the bottom, so needed a place for the power distribution board. This little build allows you to put the PDB under the controller in the central well area of this frame. Then you can mount your controller on top for easy access. The pictures tell the whole story.
The platform is 11mm high, so should be flush or slightly higher than the top of the frame... that should provide enough room unless you want to jam more stuff underneath, or have sloppy wiring like I usually do.
I haven't really figured out a good way to keep the thing intact in the well area yet, so I'm just taping it for now. Will hopefully work out something better.
There are ample slots for wires to come out to all the important parts of your quad.

title: Spool hub for the Heavy Duty Filament spool for mendel

description.text:
Some time back I printed off the Heavy Duty filament spool (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11447) and love it. It keeps my filament out of the way mounted to my printer. However my recent batches of filament are coming on spools already but I don't want to mess with any other form of filament system. The solution was a hub that is compatible with the mount (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:10254) of the filament spool system but is designed to hold the new spools.
Spool has a center hole 76mm in diameter but is too thick for the mount. The solution was to print a pair of these hubs, one for each side of the spool, with bolts holding them in place through the center of the spool.
My printer is currently down for further upgrades so have not had the chance to get this printed to test it out.

This is a shim to improve the mounting of an E3D extruder in a Bull Dog all Metal extruder. I have included 3 different sizes but use the 1.4 mm shim without sanding.

Print at .2mm layer height.

Hi, I didnt want to wait for my carbon rods to arrive, so I made this part to prototype. Please note, these should prob not support a heavy camera. My up!mini has a 4" bed, so this is as large as I could make them.  This is a very simple part, but hopefully it helps someone.

Mount McLoughlin in the Siskiyou National Forest in Oregon constructed with 1 arcsecond resolution SRTM data from the Space Shuttle. This is an update to a previous version using 3 arc second data. This is using a new and, as yet, unreleased version of SRTM2STL. The source code for creating files at 3 arcsecond resolution is available up on github under the GNU license. Go to github and search for SRTM2STL. I hope to release the new software as soon as I get any kinks out.

You may want to print this to be relatively small. I get warping using PLA and it gets bad when I try to print Raised Relief Maps that are big. I have had 'some' success with big maps. If you have a way to control warping you may also have better luck with big maps.

Here is my version of a NEMA 17 motor mount. That is the size of the stepper motors used on a MakerBot. There are several other motor mounts on Thingiverse, but none of them would work for what I had in mind. This one is designed to fit the stepper motor onto 1" X 1" (25mm X 25mm) 80/20 series 10 aluminum T-slot framing. The mounting holes will accept 1/4" (M6) size bolts - which is the size the 80/20 uses for its T-bolts. A note about 80/20 Aluminum ( http://www.8020.net - I have no affiliation):
If you crossed a Gilbert Erector Set with dimensional lumber (2x4, 1x6, etc.), you'd get 80/20 extruded aluminum. I'd never heard of it until I started playing with 3D printing and looked over several DIY websites which featured projects using it. Neat stuff. The 80/20 company has stocking distributors across the USA, but I'm guessing they are only interested in large orders and could care less about the DIY market. There are several web based vendors of the 80/20 parts. For me it was WAY easier to order through Amazon rather then try to figure out how to buy from any of the large raw material websites. I also see there are 1,000s of 80/20 parts being auctioned on eBay.

Printing takes about an hour and because of this item's size, using an HBP is a requirement to avoid curl. Be sure to center up your XY platform good as the mount is 83mm wide. I printed the mount with a raft which was left on to add a little more strength to the face of the mount - uh, plus it was fused too good and did not cause any harm. To print this raftless, your HBP has to be leveled real good. Something just beyond what I could get mine to handle lately. SkeinForge:
INFILL DENSITY in FILL was set to .2 which looks like it prints almost 100% for most of the object due to the narrow geometry of the 3 main surfaces. Your results are sure to be different, but I suggest trying .2 or even .1 INFILL DENSITY on your 1st printing attempt. Little post-printing work is needed. Remove the excess plastic with an X-acto knife and clean out the 4 motor mount holes with an 1/8" (M3) drill bit. The 2 1/4" (M6) holes that hold the mount to the frame you are using can also be cleaned out with an X-acto knife.

comments.text: I use LightWave 9.2.  Not the easiest 3D CAD software, or the cheapest, but it was what I could learn after trying to use Blender.
comments.author: TheMadScientist

comments.text: Had three of these with 25% infill using abs, nice and solid and the mounting holes with M3 screws gives you a little play to adjust position, think these are almost perfect. did not use any washers when they are mounted to the 80/20 1010 frame i will use washers and maybe install a fiber gasket between the frame and the motor. since some seem to think there may be some noise, they seem to be well designed, mounted mine with 10/32 screws and T-tabs (think this will work very nice) thank for providing the design,
comments.author: recoush

comments.text: if you make the motor stick out slightly you can have it tensioned against the tslot which would reduce vibration and also act as a heatsink.
comments.author: DFarms

comments.text: If you just 'biased' cleaning out the 4 motor mounting holes toward the base, or used a 3/16th drill bit for cleaning out the holes, the motor would touch the aluminum T-slot.  The motor is so close to the T-slot with this existing mount, that you almost have to be careful if you do not want it to touch.  I should try what you suggest just to see if noise is reduced or increased.  The motor heatsinking would be improved for sure.
comments.author: DFarms

comments.text: you could even just shim in some pennies haha, or copper sheet.
comments.author: ElectronicKit

comments.text: In the top view, the layers in the printed black object look almost identical to the stack of black iron laminates in the motor!  Like you meant to do that!
comments.author: Liberty4Ever

comments.text: Thank you for the feedback - I had not noticed the iron laminate look produced by the base interface layer.
comments.author: Liberty4Ever

comments.text: Can't quite tell, but is the motor actually in contact (or nearly) with the beam?
comments.author: alansblue

comments.text: Hard to tell from my photos, but there is a .03" (.76mm) space between the motor housing and the 80/20 frame surface. The motor is mounted on the frame here, but I have not fired up the prototype to get an idea of noise. There is enough play in the motor mounting holes to actually put the motor into conatact with the aluminum beam. At this point, I don't know if that is a good thing or not for vibration and/or noise.
comments.author: alansblue

comments.text: I would guess that this is worse for vibration, as you won't have the mass of the frame to dampen things out.  You could end up with the stepper vibration just being enough to have the frame and motor housing hitting each other a bunch.

This is a re-mix of the GoPro compatible base made by jetbeetle (thing: 520739). The only difference is that the two outer track ways are braced to provide strength. The GoPro mount plate is a tight fit and has strong springs on the prongs. The braces help to prevent the layers of the 3D print from shearing.

This part was printed in abs with 0.254 mm layer height and 50% fill on a home built original model Printrbot 3D printer. Kisslicer was used to slice the file. Model orientation was transformed with Y => up. Coarse support was used to make clean overhangs on the outer track ways. The support material cleaned off easily with a hobby knife..

author: AwesomeA

description.text:
Remember Spirograph? Now available in 3d!
Classic spirograph involves rotating one cog around the inside or outside of another fixed cog. A pen is used through a hole in the rotating cog to trace out a spirograph pattern.
The spirograph vase extends this to the third dimension by extruding and twisting the spirograph pattern.
The parameters describing the "rotating cog" radius, "fixed cog" radius and distance of the "pen" determine the shape and pattern of the walls of the vase - which can take on many forms. You can then twist the resulting pattern and raise to whatever height you require.

Open in customiser to generate your own custom STL. Note the render time is slow, so wait for the render to complete before changing another field otherwise the result may not match what you have in the customiser. The vase shape and complexity is dependent on the ratio of the radius of the fixed to rotating cog, the number of turns and the distance of the virtual pen. Some settings will generate relatively simple, but attractive patterns, others will be highly complex. Experiment here to try things out quickly: http://www.artbylogic.com/spirographart/spirograph.htm The number of nodes is dependent on the ratio of the fixed to rotating cog. If this ratio is integer then you'll only need one turn otherwise you'll need to increase "turns" to complete the pattern - however increasing it further will just trace out the same path. Fine precision and layer height will cause very slow render times - note the layer height does not need to be really fine to produce smooth curves. You can specify parameters which are not possible with a real spirograph such as the pen distance larger than the radius. Tips:
  • Render times can be very slow. Try out some spirograph parameters somewhere like this: http://www.artbylogic.com/spirographart/spirograph.htm The default should render in a minute or two, whereas fine resolution may take hours.
  • For vases with a large number of "nodes" on the spirograph circumference you'll need to increase the number of segments and hence the render time.
  • Setting the wall width to the same as your nozzle won't necessarily produce a good single walled print because unfortunately the slicer is unlikely to follow the spirograph path.
  • These vases can form slicer torture tests with endless retraction and lobes not sticking to the main vase - you should be able to improve this by adjusting wall widths and other parameters.

This is a mounting plate for a Prusa Mendel LCD Controller. It was originally designed for a "RepRapDiscount Smart Controller" mounted in the case "Case for RepRapDiscount Smart Controller" (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:35438). The mounting plate is parametrized. It can be easily adapted for almost anything you want to mount on you Prusa Mendel using the 2 top bars.

You will need:
  • a mounting plate (this Thing)
  • 2 (4) "2-way Prusa bar clamp" (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5786) or any other 90 degrees bar clamp such as "Rescue Bar Clamp - without disassembling of Prusa Mendel" (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:33772)
  • a 4"1/2 (11.5 cm) 8 mm threaded rod
  • 4 8 mm washers
  • 4 8mm nuts
  • optionally 2 screws or/and glue to mount the display on the mounting plate.
    • Assemble the above as shown in the pictures of this Thing. 5/16" rods can also be used. The "2-way Prusa bar clamp" is a bit fragile. Print the "beefy" ones with a few spare ones. Do not over tight the nuts. Larger 8 mm washers are preferable.

description.text:
V2 of this exists at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:699285
.
Well, the original parts someone nicely made for me finally had one break and it was the X-Idler at the 624zz location. So, I went out to make my own and to use what I already had on hand.
If you look at the picture of mine it is the beta version and what I am uploading here is a version with the slight issues I found fixed. I will be printing this now that I have a non broken X-Idler but if you look at that picture I am surprised it held as that is the worst print I have ever gotten but to be expected when the X-Idler bearing is about to fall out on you.
.
.
This is 5mm wider than the original as I added that to help reinforce it but can easily be removed in the source.

Use the M4 Screw and nut you already have and for the tensioning part use M3x25mm, 3mm Flat Washer, and a M3 nut.

I liked the design of this box, but I saw some room for improvement. I rewrote the code from scratch to add the following features:
  • Add holes right up to the corners--this saves an additional 15 to 20% of plastic and I think it looks a bit nicer.
  • Parameters for things like hole size and spacing.
  • Holes are automatically generated and should fill any size box.
  • Added angles under horizontal surfaces to allow printing without supports.
    The customizer has a little trouble rendering but it should generate a good model.

This is a printable motor mount for a carbon fibre tube that can be used on my printed quad or any other multi rotor. Choose from list of sizes. All sizes are outer diameter of CF tube. Donate Update 7/3/13: I've added the sketchup file for the motor mounts and the spacers. Update 5/12/13: This project kinda fell to the back burner for a bit. I have uploaded 8 new files for motor mounts. There are two styles, round and teardrop. There are also 4 different types depending on your needs. Unfortunately there is just the 9/16th diameter at the moment. Now that I have the designs finalized I will begin to add other common arm diameters. Stay tuned.

Print at 100% infill for the "Clamp" style mount and use 6/32 hardware to secure to carbon fibre tube.  Do not over tighten.  The other mounts can be printed at 50%.  You can either use a 6/32 as a set screw or a few drops of super glue.

description.text:
This box matches the Stacking screw and tool boxes but instead of a solid base, I've used a grid of 1.6 mm i.e. 2 perimeters at 0.4 mm nozzle so that it prints quickly (about an hour at 0.3mm layer height)
Insert a piece of card/paper (195 mm * 95 mm) into the base before use.
There's a SCAD file it you'd like to play...

comments.text:
I like the basket idea .
(less plastic! (I am cheap).
one other direction I can see going with the boxes,
flat print sides with dovetails to "snap" together.
would allow for boxes larger than the print bed to
be printed in pieces.
and the mesh (for sides) would not rely on bridging
(which is not a consistent behavior across machines & filaments).
comments.author: cerberus333

comments.text: Thanks, for me it's the structure and the time to print (and a little bit cheap), I might have a play with the mesh panels idea. Probably less dovetail and more interlocking and held in place by whatever is in the box.  As far as printing meshes vertically, not only do you have poor bridging and lots of small details, the strength is appalling.
comments.author: cerberus333

comments.text: Love the clever print-time-saving idea of the supporting grid at the bottom. Thanks for sharing!
